newsitem.title: USA: OPTIONS - Short-dated FX volatilities tiptoe lower.
newsitem.headline: OPTIONS - Short-dated FX volatilities tiptoe lower.

text.p: Shorter-dated forex option volatilities tiptoed lower as traders tried to trim some time decay out of their books, despite a general wariness to be short options after a very volatile week, dealers said.

With the dollar drifting in the 115-116 yen range today, more than three yen above Tuesday's 111.98 yen low, and a long weekend coming up in the United States and Britain, traders said they were reluctantly selling gamma-rich short dates.
"Obviously, people are trying to save some time decay or earn some time decay by selling the front end of the curve," said a dealer at a U.S. bank in California.

Short-dated options, which have higher time-decay rates but also have higher gamma acceleration, had become very plump during the dollar's recent tumble as many dealers were forced to cover their negative gamma positions.
"It (the front end) is very expensive, and with the long weekend you're talking about some serious time decay," a U.S. bank trader in Chicago said.

One-week dollar/yen volatility fell to 13.0/14.5 percent by U.S. midsession, down from 14.5/15.5 late on Thursday and around 20 on Tuesday. One-month lost about half a point to 11.8/12.2 percent and one-year was off 0.1 point at 10.4/10.6.
Still, traders noted that selling was probably limited to what was necessary to control theta decay, as opposed to outright speculation of lower volatilities.
"You're not going to get them back cheaply on Tuesday," the Chicago trader predicted. "When we walk in Tuesday morning, the front end is going to be well bid."
Monday is a public holiday in the U.S. and Britain.

The California trader added that risk reversals, the cost of swapping equally out-of-the-money puts and calls, had narrowed somewhat but were still heavily favoring yen calls, reflecting lingering concerns about a further dollar slide.
"The market is still very much skewed toward the dollar's downside," he said. "Obviously if dollar/yen was to push lower again, we'll definitely have a volatility appreciation."
One-month 25-delta was pegged at 0.8/1.1 point in favor of yen calls, shrinking by about 0.2 point on the day.

Similar nervousness about possible breakouts in the near future kept dollar/mark volatilities little changed with the curve remaining very flat, despite continued range-trading in spot around the 1.69-mark level today.
One-month dollar/mark volatility stood at 9.1/9.3 percent, off 0.2 point, while one-year was steady at 9.0/9.2.
"I tend to believe that this might be the calm before a storm," the California trader said.

He said the relatively small directional preference, as reflected in one-month 25-delta risk reversals at 0.1/0.3 point skewed for mark calls, showed that the market was not positioned for a sharp dollar move.

"My feeling is that if we break 1.6750, vols are going to jump," he said. He added that the market had been tinkering with a trendline support drawn from November lows coming in at around 1.6850 marks today.
